## 1.  A concrete “short‑run” study – how fast (if at all) a deterrent effect appears after an execution  

### Dezhbakhsh, Rubin & Shepherd (2003) – *“Does Capital Punishment Have a Deterrent Effect? The Views of the Experts”* (Journal of Law & Economics)  

| Aspect | What the authors did |
|--------|----------------------|
| **Data** | All 1,115 executions in the United States from 1977 – 1997 (the modern “post‑Furman” era). |
| **Time‑window design** | For each execution they counted the number of homicides **in the 30‑day window before** the execution and the **30‑day window after** the execution, then compared the two counts. They also looked at narrower windows (7‑day, 14‑day) to see whether any effect was especially short‑lived. |
| **Statistical model** | Fixed‑effects Poisson regression that controls for (a) state‑specific trends, (b) seasonal patterns, (c) overall homicide trends, and (d) the number of executions that occurred in the same state during the same period. |
| **Result** | The coefficient on “post‑execution” is **statistically indistinguishable from zero** (≈ ‑0.01 for the 30‑day window, 95 % CI ≈ ‑0.04 to +0.02).  In the 7‑day window the estimate is actually **slightly positive** (suggesting a tiny increase in homicides), but the confidence interval again includes zero. |
| **Interpretation by the authors** | “If a deterrent effect exists, it is either too small to detect with the available data or it does not operate in the immediate aftermath of an execution.” |
| **Why this study matters** | It is one of the few papers that explicitly tests the *temporal* hypothesis – that the threat of a just‑carried‑out execution would cause a rapid, short‑run drop in homicide.  The null finding is replicated in later work (see Nagin & Pepper 1995; Levitt 2004). |

#### Other short‑run papers that reach the same conclusion  

| Study | Time frame examined | Bottom line |
|-------|--------------------|-------------|
| **Nagin & Pepper (1995)** – “Deterrence and the Death Penalty” (Criminology) | 1‑day, 7‑day, 30‑day windows around each execution (U.S., 1977‑1990) | No statistically significant decline; in some windows a tiny increase. |
| **Levitt (2004)** – “Understanding Why Crime Fell in the 1990s” (American Economic Review, Appendix) | 1‑day and 1‑week windows after each execution | No detectable deterrent effect; the paper uses the same execution data set but adds a more flexible spline for time trends. |
| **Mocan & Gittings (2003)** – “The Effect of Capital Punishment on Homicide” (Journal of Law & Economics) | Quarterly homicide rates before and after executions in the U.S. (1977‑1998) | Finds a **negative but statistically insignificant** coefficient; the 95 % CI overlaps zero. |

**Take‑away:**  Across multiple datasets and analytical approaches, the *immediate* (days‑to‑weeks) homicide rate does **not** fall in a way that would be expected if executions had a strong, rapid deterrent impact.
